newsitem.title: USA: GT Interactive falls on Wal-Mart decision.
newsitem.headline: GT Interactive falls on Wal-Mart decision.

text.p: GT Interactive Software Corp shares fell as much as 11 percent Tuesday after Wal-Mart Stores Inc said it would start buying video game software titles directly from producers.

GT Interactive, which acts as a distributor or wholesaler for video game companies, performing as the middleman between the companies and big retailers like Wal-Mart, was off 3/8 at 7-1/16 in early afternoon Nasdaq trading.
Earlier the shares traded as low as 6-5/8.

On Monday Wal-Mart said it would begin testing direct purchasing of software from three software publishers in the 1997 second half, cutting GT Interactive out of the loop. Wal-Mart said it would buy directly from CUC International Inc, Electronic Arts Inc and LucasArts Entertainment.
Resale of titles from those three companies accounted for about $20 million of GT Interactive's 1996 revenues of $365.5 million.
New York-based GT Interactive, which also writes game software for video game consoles and personal computers, said Wal-Mart's plan would not "materially affect its 1997 earnings."
